titleStmt.title: Verfahren zur Kombination der Leitflossensteuerung
A fin command mixing method
Méthode de combinaison de commande d'aileron

div.p:
Verfahren zur Betätigung eines Fahrzeugs mit dem Schritt des Zuordnens eines Rollbefehls (δRc) zu mindestens einer aus einer Mehrzahl von Leitwerksflächen in Abhängigkeit von einem Steigungsbefehl (δPc) und einem Gierbefehl (δYc), dadurch gekennzeichnet, daß der Schritt der Zuordnung folgende Schritte umfaßt:
a) Errechnen eines Steigungs-/Roll-Befehlsverhältnisses gleich einem Absolutwert des Ergebnisses der Division des Steigungsbefehls (δPc) durch den Rollbefehl (δRc), und Errechnen eines Gier-/Roll-Befehlverhältnisses gleich einem Absolutwert des Ergebnisses der Division des Gierbefehls (δYc) durch den Rollbefehl (δRc);
b) voneinander Abziehen des Gier-/Roll-Befehlsverhältnisses und des Steigungs-/Roll-Befehlverhältnisses zur Bildung eines Differenzwertes; und
c) Zuordnen des Rollbefehls (δRc) zu mindestens einer der Mehrzahl von Leitwerksflächen in Relation zur Größe des genannten Differenzwertes.

Verfahren nach Anspruch 1, dadurch gekennzeichnet, daß der Schritt des Zuordnens des Rollbefehls (δRc) weiter folgende Schritte umfaßt:
a) Zuordnen dann, wenn der Differenzwert des Gier-/Roll-Befehlsverhältnisses, subtrahiert von dem Steigungs-/Roll-Befehlsverhältnis, gleich oder größer als 0,5 ist, den Rollbefehl (δRc) in gleicher Weise zu Gier-Leitwerksflächen;
b) Zuordnen dann, wenn der Differenzwert des Steigungs-/Roll-Befehlsverhältnisses, subtrahiert von dem Gier-/Roll-Befehlsverhältnis gleich oder größer als 0,5 ist, den Rollbefehl (δRc) in gleicher Weise zu Steigungs-Leitwerksflächen; und
c) Zuordnen dann, wenn der Differenzwert des Gier-/Roll-Befehlsverhältnisses, subtrahiert von dem Steigungs-/Roll-Befehlsverhältnis und der Differenzwert des Steigungs-/Roll-Befehlsverhältnisses, subtrahiert von dem Gier-/Roll-Befehlsverhältnis, kleiner als 0,5 sind, einen Teil des Rollbefehls (δRc) zu den Steigungs-Leitwerksflächen und einen Teil des Rollbefehls (δRc) zu den Gier-Leitwerksflächen.

Verfahren nach Anspruch 2, dadurch gekennzeichnet, daß der Schritt des Zuordnens eines Teiles des Rollbefehls (δRc) zu den Steigungs- und Gier-Leitwerksflächen folgende Schritte umfaßt:
a) Errechnen eines ersten Wertes gleich dem Steigungs-/Roll-Befehlsverhältnis, subtrahiert von dem Gier-/Roll-Befehlsverhältnis und Hinzuaddieren von 0,5 zu dem Ergebnis hiervon;
b) Errechnen eines zweiten Wertes gleich einer Differenz zwischen dem ersten Wert und eins; und
c) Zuordnen (52, 54) eines Teiles des Rollbefehls (δRc) in Entsprechung zu dem ersten Wert zu den Steigungs-Leitwerksflächen und eines Teiles des Rollbefehls in Entsprechung zu dem zweiten Wert zu den Gier-Leitwerksflächen.

Verfahren nach Anspruch 4, dadurch gekennzeichnet, daß der Schritt des Zuordnens eines Teils des Rollbefehls zu den Gier- und Steigungs-Leitwerksflächen folgende Schritte umfaßt:
a) Errechnen eines dritten Differenzwertes gleich dem Steigungs-/Roll-Befehlsverhältnis, subtrahiert von dem Gier-/Roll-Befehlsverhältnis und Hinzuaddieren von 0,5 zu dem Ergebnis hiervon;
b) Errechnen eines vierten Differenzwertes gleich dem dritten Differenzwert, subtrahiert von eins; und
c) Zuordnen eines Teiles des Rollbefehls in Entsprechung zu dem dritten Differenzwert zu den Steigungs-Leitwerksflächen und Zuordnen eines Teiles des Rollbefehls in Entsprechung zu dem vierten Differenzwert zu den Gier-Leitwerksflächen.

Einrichtung zur Betätigung eines Fahrzeugs, welche Mittel (14) zur Zuordnung eines Rollbefehls (δRc) zu mindestens einer aus einer Mehrzahl von Leitwerksflächen in Abhängigkeit von einem Steigungsbefehl (δPc) und einem Gier-Befehl (δYc) aufweist, dadurch gekennzeichnet, daß die Zuordnungsmittel (14) folgendes umfassen:
a) Einrichtungen (50) zur Bildung eines Steigungs-/Roll-Befehlsverhältnisses und eines Gier-/Roll-Befehlverhältnisses und zur Differenzbildung zwischen dem Gier-/Roll-Befehlsverhältnis und dem Steigungs-/Roll-Befehlsverhältnis zur Bildung eines Differenzwertes, wobei das Steigungs-/Roll-Befehlsverhältnis gleich einem Absolutwert des Ergebnisses des Steigungsbefehls dividiert durch den Rollbefehl ist und das Gier-/Roll-Befehlsverhältnis gleich einem Absolutwert des Ergebnisses des Gierbefehls dividiert durch den Rollbefehl ist; und
b) Einrichtungen (52, 54) zur Bildung eines zugeordneten Rollbefehls zu mindestens einer aus einer Anzahl von Leitwerksflächen in Abhängigkeit von dem genannten Differenzwert.
Einrichtung nach Anspruch 6, gekennzeichnet durch Mittel (12) zur Lieferung des Steigungsbefehls (δPc) , des Gierbefehls (δYc) und des Rollbefehls (δRc).

Einrichtung nach Anspruch 7, dadurch gekennzeichnet, daß die Leitwerksflächen Steigungs-Leitflossen und Gier-Leitflossen (1, 2, 3, 4) sind, und daß die Einrichtungen zur Lieferung eines zugeordneten Rollbefehls weiter folgendes enthalten:
a) Mittel (52, 64, 68; 54, 62, 66), welche auf den Differenzwert ansprechen und entweder den gesamten zugeordneten Rollbefehl an die Gier-Leitflossen, oder den gesamten zugeordneten Rollbefehl an die Steigungs-Leitflossen liefern; und
b) Mittel (52, 54, 62, 64, 66, 68), welche auf den Differenzwert ansprechen und abhängig hiervon einen Teil des zugeordneten Rollbefehls zu den Gier-Leitflossen liefern und einen Teil des zugeordneten Rollbefehls zu den Steigungs-Leitflossen liefern.

Einrichtung nach Anspruch 8, dadurch gekennzeichnet, daß die Zuordnungsmittel (14, 50) solcher Art sind, daß
a) der ganze zugeordnete Rollbefehl an die Gier-Leitflossen geliefert wird, wenn der Differenzwert des Gier-/Roll-Befehlsverhältnisses subtrahiert von dem Steigungs-/Roll-Befehlsverhältnis gleich oder größer als 0,5 ist;
b) der gesamte zugeordnete Rollbefehl an die Steigungs-Leitflossen geliefert wird, wenn der Differenzwert des Steigungs-/Roll-Befehlsverhältnisses, subtrahiert von dem Gier-/Roll-Befehlsverhältnis gleich oder größer gleich 0,5 ist; und
c) dann, wenn die Differenzwerte des Gier-/Roll-Befehlsverhältnisses, subtrahiert von dem Steigungs-/Roll-Befehlsverhältnis, und des Steigungs-Roll-Befehlsverhältnisses, subtrahiert von dem Gier-/Roll-Befehlsverhältnis kleiner als 0,5 sind, der Teil des
zugeordneten Rollbefehls, der an die Steigungs-Leitflossen geliefert wird, zu dem Rollbefehl, multipliziert mit einem ersten Wert, in Beziehung gesetzt ist, wobei der erste Wert gleich dem Steigungs-/Roll-Befehlsverhältnis subtrahiert von dem Gier-/Roll-Befehlsverhältnis und Hinzunahme von 0,5 zum Ergebnis hieraus ist, und der Teil des zugeordneten Rollbefehls, der zu den Gier-Leitflossen geliefert ist, in Beziehung gesetzt wird zu dem Rollbefehl, multipliziert mit einem zweiten Wert, wobei ein zweiter Wert gleich einer Differenz zwischen eins und dem ersten Wert ist.

A method of operating a vehicle comprising the step of apportioning, in response to a pitch command (δPc) and a yaw command (δYc), a roll command (δRc) to at least one of a plurality of control surfaces, characterised in that the step of apportioning comprises the steps of:
(a) calculating a pitch-to-roll command ratio equal to an absolute value of the result of the pitch command (δPc) divided by the roll command (δRc), and calculating a yaw-to-roll command ratio equal to an absolute value of the result of the yaw command (δYc) divided by the roll command (δRc);
(b) differencing the yaw-to-roll command ratio with the pitch-to-roll command ratio to provide a difference value; and
(c) apportioning the roll command (δRc) to at least one of the plurality of control surfaces in relation to the value of said difference value.

A method according to claim 1, characterised in that the step of apportioning the roll command (δRc) further comprises the steps of:
(a) apportioning, if the difference value of the yaw-to-roll command ratio subtracted from the pitch-to-roll command ratio is equal to or greater than 0.5, the roll command (δRc) equally to yaw control surfaces;
(b) apportioning, if the difference value of the pitch-to-roll command ratio subtracted from the yaw-to-roll command ratio is equal to or greater than 0.5, the roll command (δRc) equally to pitch control surfaces; and
(c) apportioning, if the difference values of the yaw-to-roll command ratio subtracted from the pitch-to-roll command ratio and the pitch-to-roll command ratio subtracted from the yaw-to-roll command ratio are less than 0.5, a portion of the roll command (δRc) to the pitch control surfaces and a portion of the roll command (δRc) to the yaw control surfaces.

A method according to claim 2, characterised in that the step of apportioning a portion of the roll command (δRc) to the pitch and yaw control surfaces comprises the steps of:
(a) calculating a first value equal to the pitch-to-roll command ratio subtracted from the yaw-to-roll command ratio and adding 0.5 to the result thereof;
(b) calculating a second value equal to a difference between the first value and unity; and
(c) apportioning (52,54) a portion of the roll command (δRc) related to the first value to the pitch control surfaces and a portion of the roll command (δRc) related to the second value to the yaw control surfaces.

A method according to claim 4, characterised in that the step of apportioning a portion of the roll command to the yaw and the pitch control surfaces comprises the steps of:
(a) calculating a third difference value equal to the pitch-to-roll command ratio subtracted from the yaw-to-roll command ratio and adding 0.5 to the result thereof;
(b) calculating a fourth difference value equal to the third difference value subtracted from unity; and
(c) apportioning a portion of the roll command related to the third difference value to the pitch control surfaces and apportioning a portion of the roll command related to the fourth difference value to the yaw control surfaces.

Apparatus for operating a vehicle, the apparatus comprising means (14) for apportioning, in response to a pitch command (δPc) and a yaw command (δYc), a roll command (δRc) to at least one of a plurality of control surfaces, characterised in that the apportioning means (14) comprises:
(a) means (50) for providing a pitch-to-roll command ratio and a yaw-to-roll command ratio and for differencing the yaw-to-roll command ratio with the
pitch-to-roll command ratio to provide a difference value, the pitch-to-roll command ratio being equal to an absolute value of the result of the pitch command divided by the roll command, and the yaw-to-roll command ratio being equal to an absolute value of the result of the yaw command divided by the roll command; and
(b) means (52,54) for providing an apportioned roll command to at least one of a plurality of control surfaces in response to said difference value.
Apparatus according to claim 6, characterised by means (12) for providing the pitch command (δPc), the yaw command (δYc), and the roll command (δRc).

Apparatus according to claim 7, characterised in that the control surfaces are pitch and yaw control fins (1,2,3,4) and the means for providing an apportioned roll command further comprises:
(a) means (52,64,68; 54,62,66), in response to the difference value, for providing all of the apportioned roll command to the yaw fins and, alternatively, for providing all of the apportioned roll command to the pitch fins; and
(b) means (52,54,62,64,66,68), in response to the difference value, for providing a portion of the apportioned roll command to the yaw fins and for providing a portion of the apportioned roll command to the pitch fins.

Apparatus according to claim 8, characterised in that the apportioning means (14,50) is such that:
(a) if the difference value of the yaw-to-roll command ratio subtracted from the pitch-to-roll command
ratio is equal to or greater than 0.5, then all of the apportioned roll command is provided to the yaw fins;
(b) if the difference value of the pitch-to-roll command ratio subtracted from the yaw-to-roll command ratio is equal to or greater than 0.5, then all of the apportioned roll command is provided to the pitch fins; and
(c) if the difference values of the yaw-to-roll command ratio subtracted from the pitch-to-roll command ratio and the pitch-to-roll command ratio subtracted from the yaw-to-roll command ratio are less than 0.5, then the portion of the apportioned roll command that is provided to the pitch fins is related to the roll command multiplied by a first value, the first value equal to the pitch-to-roll command ratio subtracted from the yaw-to-roll command ratio and adding 0.5 to the result thereof, and the portion of the apportioned roll command that is provided to the yaw fins is related to the roll command multiplied by a second value, the second value equal to a difference between unity and the first value.

Procédé pour manoeuvrer un véhicule comprenant l'étape consistant à répartir, en réponse à une commande de tangage (δPc) et une commande de lacet (δYc), une commande de roulis (δRc) vers au moins une parmi une pluralité de surfaces de commande, caractérisé en ce que l'étape de répartition comprend les étapes consistant à :
(a) calculer un rapport de commande tangage sur roulis égal à la valeur absolue du résultat de la commande de tangage (δPc) divisée par la commande de roulis (δRc), et calculer un rapport de commande lacet sur roulis égal à la valeur absolue du résultat de la commande de lacet (δYc) divisée par la commande de roulis (δRc) ;
(b) soustraire le rapport de commande lacet sur roulis du rapport de commande tangage sur roulis pour obtenir une valeur de différence ; et
(c) répartir la commande de roulis (δRc) à au moins une de la pluralité de surfaces de commande en fonction de la valeur de ladite valeur de différence.

Procédé selon la revendication 1, caractérisé en ce que l'étape consistant à répartir la commande de roulis (δRc) comprend en outre les étapes consistant à :
(a) répartir, si la valeur de différence du rapport de commande lacet sur roulis soustrait du rapport de commande tangage sur roulis est égale ou supérieure à 0,5, la commande de roulis (δRc) également entre les surfaces de commande de lacet ;
(b) répartir, si la valeur de différence du rapport de commande tangage sur roulis soustrait du rapport de commande lacet sur roulis est égale ou supérieure à 0,5, la commande de roulis (δRc) également entre les surfaces de commande de tangage ; et
(c) répartir, si les valeurs de différence du rapport de commande lacet sur roulis soustrait du rapport de commande tangage sur roulis et du rapport de commande tangage sur roulis soustrait du rapport de commande lacet sur roulis sont inférieures à 0,5, une portion de la commande de
roulis (δRc) vers les surfaces de commande de tangage et une portion de la commande de roulis (δRc) vers les surfaces de commande de lacet.

Procédé selon la revendication 2, caractérisé en ce que l'étape consistant à répartir une portion de la commande de roulis (δRc) vers les surfaces de commande de tangage et de lacet comprend les étapes consistant à :
(a) calculer une première valeur égale au rapport de commande tangage sur roulis soustrait du rapport de commande lacet sur roulis et ajouter 0,5 au résultat obtenu ;
(b) calculer une deuxième valeur égale à une différence entre la première valeur et l'unité ; et
(c) répartir (52, 54) une portion de la commande de roulis (δRc) associée à la première valeur vers les surfaces de commande de tangage et une portion de la commande de roulis (δRc) associée à la deuxième valeur vers les surfaces de commande de lacet.

Procédé selon la revendication 4, caractérisé en ce que l'étape consistant à répartir une portion de la commande de roulis vers les surfaces de commande de lacet de tangage comprend les étapes consistant à :
(a) calculer une troisième valeur de différence égale au rapport de commande tangage sur roulis soustrait du rapport de commande lacet sur roulis et ajouter 0,5 au résultat obtenu ;
(b) calculer une quatrième valeur de différence égale à la troisième valeur de différence soustraite de l'unité ; et
(c) répartir une portion de la commande de roulis associée à la troisième valeur de différence vers les surfaces de commande de tangage et répartir une portion de la commande de roulis associée à la quatrième valeur de différence vers les surfaces de commande de lacet.

Appareil pour manoeuvrer un véhicule, l'appareil comprenant des moyens (14) pour répartir, en réponse à une commande de tangage (δPc) et une commande de lacet (δYc), une commande de roulis (δRc) vers au moins une parmi une pluralité de surfaces de commande, caractérisé en ce que les moyens de répartition (14) comprennent :
(a) des moyens (50) pour fournir un rapport de commande tangage sur roulis et un rapport de commande lacet sur roulis et pour soustraire le rapport de commande lacet sur roulis du rapport de commande tangage sur roulis afin d'obtenir une valeur de différence, le rapport de commande tangage sur roulis étant égal à la valeur absolue du résultat de la commande de tangage divisée par la commande de roulis, et le rapport de commande lacet sur roulis étant égal à la valeur absolue du résultat de la commande de lacet divisée par la commande de roulis ; et
(b) des moyens (52, 54) pour fournir une commande répartie de roulis à au moins une d'une pluralité de surfaces de commande en réponse à ladite valeur de différence.
Appareil selon la revendication 6, caractérisé par des moyens (12) pour fournir la commande de tangage (δPc), la commande de lacet (δYc), et la commande de roulis (δRc).

Appareil selon la revendication 7, caractérisé en ce que les surfaces de commande sont des ailerons de tangage et de lacet (1, 2, 3, 4) et les moyens pour fournir une commande répartie de roulis comprennent en outre :
(a) des moyens (52, 64, 68 ; 54, 62, 66), en réponse à la valeur de différence, pour fournir la totalité de la commande répartie de roulis aux ailerons de lacet et, autrement, pour fournir la totalité de la commande répartie de roulis aux ailerons de tangage ; et
(b) des moyens (52, 54, 62, 64, 66, 68), en réponse à la valeur de différence, pour fournir une portion de la commande répartie de roulis aux ailerons de lacet et pour fournir une portion de la commande répartie de roulis aux ailerons de tangage.

Appareil selon la revendication 8, caractérisé en ce que les moyens de répartition (14, 50) sont tels que :
(a) si la valeur de différence du rapport de commande lacet sur roulis soustrait du rapport de commande tangage sur roulis est égale ou supérieure à 0,5, alors la totalité de la commande répartie de roulis est fournie aux ailerons de lacet ;
(b) si la valeur de différence du rapport de commande tangage sur roulis soustrait du rapport de commande lacet sur roulis est égale ou supérieure à 0,5, alors la totalité de la commande répartie de roulis est fournie aux ailerons de tangage ; et
(c) si les valeurs de différence du rapport de commande lacet sur roulis soustrait du rapport de commande tangage sur roulis et du rapport de commande tangage sur roulis soustrait du rapport de commande lacet sur roulis sont inférieures à 0,5, alors la portion de la commande répartie de roulis qui est fournie aux ailerons de tangage est associée à la valeur de commande de roulis multipliée par une
première valeur, la première valeur étant égale au rapport de commande tangage sur roulis soustrait du rapport de commande lacet sur roulis en ajoutant 0,5 au résultat obtenu, et la portion de la commande répartie de roulis qui est fournie aux ailerons de lacet est associée à la valeur de commande de roulis multipliée par une deuxième valeur, la deuxième valeur étant égale à la différence entre l'unité et la première valeur.

This invention relates to a method of operating a vehicle comprising the step of apportioning, in response to a pitch command and a yaw command, a roll command to at least one of a plurality of control surfaces.

The method can be applied generally to flight vehicles and particularly to airborne flight vehicles wherein four independent control surfaces are used to control flight of the airborne flight vehicle.

In a flight vehicle, control surfaces are used to provide pitch, yaw and roll control of the flight vehicle. For example, control surfaces such as control fins are used to control flight of a missile and a torpedo. Additionally, control surfaces such as jet exhaust ports are used to control flight of a torpedo in water and a vehicle in space.

As it is known, in various controlled flight vehicles, including a controlled missile, commands to control the control surfaces are produced by a guidance system in the missile and provided to an autopilot to control the flight of the missile. In one conventional missile guidance technique, a pitch command, a yaw command and a roll command are provided by the guidance system to the autopilot so that the autopilot may provide control signals to fin control circuitry to command the control fins for control of the missile.

Typically, in a missile, two control fins are used for pitch control, two orthogonally positioned control fins are used for yaw control and all four control fins are used for roll control. In an environment wherein the missile must manoeuvre, one of the control fins is deflected to a larger angle than the other control fins. Typically, the autopilot, when providing the control signals to the fin control circuitry, will apportion the roll requirement to each of the control fins and then apportion the pitch and yaw requirement. In an environment wherein a manoeuvre requires a control fin deflection greater than that capable by the control fin, then typically the roll apportionment is given priority by the autopilot and the pitch and yaw requirement is reduced to a degree that is allowed by maximum deflection of the control fin. In such a condition, the control fins cannot respond as necessary and the missile cannot manoeuvre as required.

DE-A-22 39 398 describes a method of the kind defined hereinbefore at the beginning in which control signals δ1, δ2, δ3 and δ4 for four control surfaces are derived from a pitch command ηc, a yaw command ζc, and a roll command ξc by calculation in accordance with the relationships: δ1 = ξc + ηc - Δ δ2 = ξc + ζc + Δ δ3 = ξc - ηc - Δ δ4 = ξc - ζc + Δ Δ = Δδ1 - Δδc - Δδ2 + Δδ3 - Δδ4
and Δδ1 = δi* - δiL, or δi*, where δiL is the limiting value of δi*, and δi* = ξc + ηcδ2* = ξc + ζcδ3* = ξc - ηcδ4* = ξc - ζc

With the foregoing background of this invention in mind, it is a primary object of this invention to provide a method of operating a vehicle having greater lateral manoeuvrability than known vehicles.
Another object of this invention is to provide a flight vehicle wherein control fin deflection is minimized when the flight vehicle is manoeuvring.

In accordance with the present invention, a method of the kind defined hereinbefore at the beginning is characterised in that the step of apportioning the roll command includes the steps of calculating a pitch-to-roll command ratio equal to an absolute value of the result of the pitch command divided by the roll command, and calculating a yaw-to-roll command ratio equal to an absolute value of the result of the yaw command divided by the roll command; differencing the yaw-to-roll command ratio with the pitch-to-roll command ratio to provide a difference value; and apportioning the roll command to at least one of the plurality of control surfaces in relation to the value of said difference value.
The invention also provides apparatus as defined hereinafter by claim 6.

With this arrangement, lateral manoeuvrability of the vehicle is increased by apportioning more roll to the axis having a smaller manoeuvre. The method of apportioning the roll command to the plurality of control surfaces is in accordance with the relationship among the pitch, yaw and roll commands so that the maximum deflection required by the control surfaces is minimized by apportioning more roll to either the pitch axis or the yaw axis.

In accordance with a preferred embodiment of the present invention, the step of apportioning the roll command further comprises the steps of apportioning, if the difference value of the yaw-to-roll command ratio subtracted from the pitch-to-roll command ratio is equal to or greater than 0.5, the roll command equally to the yaw command surfaces, apportioning, if the difference value of the pitch-to-roll command ratio subtracted from the yaw-to-roll command ratio is equal to or greater than 0.5, the roll command equally to the pitch control surfaces and apportioning, if the difference values of the yaw-to-roll command ratio subtracted from the pitch-to-roll command ratio and the pitch-to-roll command ratio subtracted from the yaw-to-roll command ratio are less than one-half, a portion of the roll command to the pitch control surfaces and a portion of the roll command to the yaw control surfaces.

With this arrangement, the manoeuvrability of a vehicle
including an airborne vehicle with control fins manoeuvring about a pitch plane and a yaw plane is increased, such that as a combined pitch and roll command or a combined yaw and roll command exceed a maximum control fin angular deflection or rate limit of the airborne vehicle in one of the planes, the roll command is apportioned to the alternative plane to reduce the maximum control fin angular deflection and fin rate.

A vehicle having a preferred embodiment of the present invention includes an autopilot for providing a pitch-to-roll command ratio and a yaw-to-roll command ratio and for differencing the yaw-to-roll command ratio with the pitch-to-roll command ratio to provide a difference value, and for providing a roll command to at least one of a plurality of control surfaces in response to said difference value. The autopilot can apportion the roll command among the control surfaces of the vehicle so that maximum angular deflection among the control surfaces is minimized.

The autopilot includes means, in response to the difference value, for providing, alternatively, all of the roll command to the yaw control surfaces, all of the roll command to the pitch control surfaces, or a portion of
the roll command to the yaw control surfaces and a portion of the roll command to the pitch control surfaces.

With such an arrangement, an airborne vehicle with control fins can maneuver with a greater turn rate since the deflection of the control fins are apportioned among the control fins so that maximum control fin deflection is minimized.
div.head: Brief Description of the Drawings
div.p: For a more complete understanding of this invention, reference is now made to the following description of the accompanying drawings, wherein: FIG. 1 is a sketch showing an exemplary airborne vehicle according to the invention to illustrate in the simplest and clearest manner the way in which fin deflection may be reduced; and FIG. 2 is a flow chart of a method implemented by the autopilot of FIG. 1 to provide the requisite commands contemplated by the invention.
div.head: Description of the Preferred Embodiments
div.p: Before departing on a detailed explanation of the contemplated invention, it should be appreciated that, although the vehicle is described as a missile having control fins, the vehicle could include any vehicle controlled by control surfaces such as a rocket ship in space having jet exhaust ports as control surfaces, a torpedo in water having either control fins or exhaust ports as control surfaces and a missile having jet exhaust ports.

Referring now to FIG. 1, it may be seen that a vehicle, such as an airborne vehicle and here missile 10, is shown to include a plurality of control surfaces, here control fins including control fin 1, control fin 2, control fin 3 and control fin 4. Each of the plurality of control fins is able to provide angular deflection such that the amount of angular deflection provided by each one of the plurality of control fins controls the course of flight of the missile 10. The control fins 1, 2, 3 and 4 are constructed and attached to the missile 10 in a known manner. The amount of angular deflection provided by each of the control fins 1, 2, 3 and 4 is controlled by, respectively, fin controller 16, fin controller 18, fin controller 20 and fin controller 22. Each of the fin controllers 16, 18, 20 and 22 is fed a control signal from an autopilot 14. The control signal fed from the autopilot 14 controls the amount of angular
deflection provided by control fins 1, 2, 3 and 4 as controlled by each corresponding fin controller 16, 18, 20 and 22. The autopilot 14 is fed command signals including a pitch command, δPc, a yaw command, δYc, and a roll command, δRc, from a guidance system 12. Thus, as shown, control fin 2 and control fin 4 provide control in pitch, P, (also referred to as elevation) of the missile 10 and control fin 1 and control fin 3 provide control in yaw, Y, (also referred to as azimuth) of the missile 10. The control fins 1, 2, 3 and 4 also provide control of roll, R, of the missile as described further hereinafter.

As shown in FIG. 1, it should be apparent the missile 10 includes a boresight line which is coaxial with a centerline of an antenna which is part of the guidance system 12. A target T is located some distance from the missile 10 and using the boresight line as a reference, the guidance system 12 develops a boresight error in pitch and a boresight error in yaw. Using proportional navigation in a known manner, the guidance system 12 provides the pitch command, the yaw command and the roll command to the autopilot 14 to steer the missile 10 along a trajectory to intercept the target T.

It should be appreciated that many factors are entertained by the guidance system 12 to provide the pitch, yaw and roll commands to the autopilot 14. For example, it
is known that, depending on the maneuver, a deflection by the control fins 1 and 3 to provide a control in yaw may induce a roll by the missile 10 due to the aerodynamic environment of the missile 10. Known techniques are used to correct such factors and to have an understanding of the operation of the present invention discussion of such techniques are not necessary.

Defining a Cartesian coordinate system with an X axis, a Y axis and a Z axis, viewing the missile 10 from the rear, the X axis extends along the center of the missile 10, the Y axis extends along a line provided by control fins 4 and 2 and the Z axis extends along a line provided by control fins 1 and 3. It should be appreciated a pitch plane is defined by the XZ axis and a yaw plane is defined by the XY axis. Angular fin deflection is defined by the right hand rule. Defining angular deflection by the right hand rule, a positive roll command would cause the missile 10 to roll in a clockwise direction. Completing our definition of terms, if a term δFc defines the angular deflection of each fin wherein F is one of the control fins, then δ1c defines the angular deflection of control fin 1, δ2c defines the angular deflection of control fin 2, δ3c defines the angular deflection of control fin 3 and δ4c defines the angular deflection of control fin 4. With such an arrangement, a pitch fin command δPc would equal (δ2c + δ4c)÷2, a yaw fin
command δYc would equal (δ1c + δ3c)÷2 and a roll fin command δRc would equal (δ4c - δ2c) + (δ1c - δ3c). In such a coordinate system, control fins 4 and 2 provide control of pitch, P, control fins 1 and 3 provide control of yaw, Y, and control fins 1, 2, 3 and 4 provide control of roll, R.

In a vehicle, including missile 10, the guidance system 12 provides the pitch command δPc, the yaw command δYc and the roll command δc to the autopilot 14 wherein, using the coordinate system defined hereinbefore, the autopilot 14 provides fin control signals to the respective fin controllers 16, 18, 20 and 22 causing control fins 2 and 4 to provide control of pitch, P, control fins 1 and 3 to provide control of yaw, Y, and control fins 1, 2, 3 and 4 to provide, equally, control of roll R. Thus, for example, if a pitch command of twenty-five degrees, a yaw command of ten degrees and a roll command of ten degrees is fed to the autopilot 14 from the guidance system 12, then the autopilot 14 will provide appropriate control signals to each one of the fin controllers 16, 18, 20 and 22. For this example, to accommodate the pitch command of twenty-five degrees, the autopilot 14 would provide a control signal to the fin controller 18 to deflect the control fin 2 an amount of twenty-five degrees, and provide a control signal to the fin controller 22 to deflect the control fin 4 an amount of twenty-five degree. To accommodate the yaw fin command of
ten degrees, the autopilot 14 would provide a control signal to fin controller 16 to deflect the control fin 1 an amount of ten degrees and provide a control signal to fin controller 20 to deflect the control fin 3 an amount of ten degrees. To accommodate the roll command of plus ten degrees, the autopilot 14 would modify the control signal to fin controller 16 to deflect the control fin 1 an amount of 12.5 degrees instead of ten degrees, modify the control signal to fin controller 18 to deflect the control fin 2 an amount of 22.5 degrees instead of 25 degrees, modify the control signal to fin controller 20 to deflect control fin 3 an amount of 7.5 degrees instead of ten degrees and modify the control signal to fin controller 22 to deflect control fin 4 an amount of 27.5 degrees instead of 25 degrees. Recapitulating, a pitch fin command of twenty-five degrees, a yaw fin command of ten degrees and a roll fin command of ten degrees fed to the autopilot 14 will cause the autopilot 14 to provide appropriate control signals to the respective fin controllers 16, 18, 20 and 22 so that control fin 1 is deflected 12.5 degrees, control fin 2 is deflected 22.5 degrees, control fin 3 is deflected 7.5 degrees and control fin 4 is deflected 27.5 degrees. Although satisfactory for some instances, such a configuration can be a problem. For example, if the missile 10 is configured such that control fins 1, 2, 3 and 4 can provide a maximum angular deflection
of plus or minus twenty-five degrees, then in the present example, control fin 4 cannot deflect the necessary amount. In such an environment, typically the autopilot 14 gives precedence to the roll command, so that, in the present example, control fin 4 is deflected 25 degrees, control fin 2 is deflected 20 degrees, and control fins 1 and 3 are deflected 12.5 degrees and 7.5 degrees, respectively. With such an arrangement, invoking roll command preference the pitch command is reduced to an equivalent value of 22.5°
rather than the desired 25° which thus can reduce available pitch plane maneuver. To solve such a dilemma, the present invention of a fin command mixing method as to be described can be used.

Referring now to FIGS. 1 and 2, a method of operating a vehicle, here missile 10, is shown to include apportioning the roll command such that control fin deflection is minimized. As described hereinbefore, the pitch command, δPc, the yaw command, δYc, and the roll command δRc is provided to the autopilot 14 from the guidance system 12. A pitch-to-roll command ratio is calculated equal to an absolute value of the pitch command divided by the roll command and a yaw-to-roll command ratio is calculated equal to an absolute value of the yaw command divided by the roll
command. The yaw-to-roll command ratio is differenced with the pitch-to-roll command ratio and if the result thereof is equal to or greater than a value 0.5, then all of the roll command is apportioned to the yaw fins 1 and 3,
and none of the roll command is apportioned to the pitch fins 2 and 4,
If the result of the yaw-to-roll command ratio differenced with the pitch-to-roll command ratio is less than the value 0.5, then the pitch-to-roll command ratio is differenced with the yaw-to-roll command ratio. If the result of the latter is equal to or greater than the value 0.5, then all of the roll command is apportioned to the pitch fins 2 and 4,
and none of the roll command is apportioned to the yaw fins 1, and 3,
If the result of the pitch-to-roll command ratio differenced with the yaw-to-roll command ratio is less than the value 0.5, then the roll command is apportioned between the yaw fins 1 and 3 and the pitch fins 2 and 4 in a manner as to be described.

If the value of the yaw-to-roll command ratio differenced with the pitch-to-yaw command is less than 0.5 and the value of the pitch-to-roll command ratio differenced with the yaw-to-roll value is less than 0.5, then a first portion of the roll command is apportioned to the pitch fins 2 and 4, the first portion of the roll command
being the percentage of the roll command equal to the pitch-to-roll command ratio differenced with the yaw-to-roll command ratio added to 0.5. A second portion of the roll command
being the percentage of the roll command equal to the first portion of the roll command differenced with unity is apportioned to the yaw fins 1 and 3. With such an arrangement, if the autopilot 14 of the missile 10 provides fin commands having a roll portion, a yaw portion and a
pitch portion, then the required roll command can be apportioned entirely to the pitch fins 2 and 4, if the yaw fins 1 and 3 are commanded to large deflection angles or, alternatively, the required roll command can be apportioned entirely to the yaw fins 1 and 3, if the pitch fins 2 and 4 are commanded to large deflections. If the yaw fins 1 and 3 the pitch fins 2 and 4 are sufficiently close in value (as determined by the pitch-to-roll command ratio and yaw-to-roll command ratio), then the roll command is apportioned between the pitch fins 2 and 4 and the yaw fins 1 and 3 as described hereinabove.

Now, for example, if we have an environment wherein the autopilot 14 is fed a pitch command of twenty-five degrees, a yaw command of ten degrees and a roll command of ten degrees from the guidance system 12, then the autopilot 14 will provide control signals to the fin controller 16, 18, 20 and 22 as follows. Calculating the pitch-to-roll command ratio which equals the absolute value of the pitch command, δPc, divided by the roll command, δRc, here twenty-five degrees divided by ten degrees, provides the value 2.5. Calculating the yaw-to-roll command ratio which equals the absolute value of the yaw command, δYc, divided by the roll command, δRc, here ten degrees divided by ten degrees, provides the value 1. Differencing the yaw-to-roll command ratio with the pitch-to-roll command ratio, here
2.5 - 1.0, provides the value 1.5. Since the value 1.5 is greater than the value 0.5, the portion of the roll command apportioned to the pitch fins 2 and 4 is zero,
and all of the roll command is apportioned to the yaw fins 1 and 3,
Thus, for the present example, the autopilot 14 would provide a control signal to the fin controller 16 to deflect the control fin 1 an amount of 15 degrees, provide a control signal to the fin controller 18 to deflect the control fin 2 an amount of 25 degrees, provide a control signal to the fin controller 20 to deflect the control fin 3 an amount of five degrees and provide a control signal to the fin controller 22 to deflect the control fin 4 an amount of 25 degrees.

It should now be apparent, by apportioning all of the roll command, δRc, to the yaw fins 1 and 3 and apportioning none of the roll command to the pitch fins 2 and 4, the angular deflection of control fin 4 is reduced below the angular deflection limit of 25 degrees as described in the example.

As a first alternative, if we have an environment wherein the autopilot 14 is fed a pitch command of ten degrees, a yaw command of twenty-five degrees and a roll command of ten degrees from the guidance system 12, then the autopilot 14 will provide control signals to the fin controllers 16, 18, 20 and 22 as follows. Calculating the pitch-to-roll command ratio, ten degrees divided by ten degrees, provides the value 1.0. Calculating the yaw-to-roll command ratio, twenty-five degrees divided by ten degrees, provides the value 2.5. Differencing the yaw-to-roll command ratio with the pitch-to-roll command ratio, here 1.0 - 2.5, provides the value -1.5. Since the value -1.5 is less than the value 0.5, the pitch-to-roll command ratio is differenced with the yaw-to-roll command ratio, here 2.5 - 1.0, providing the value 1.5. Since the value 1.5 is greater than the value 0.5, all of the roll command is apportioned to the pitch fins 2 and 4,
and none of the roll command is apportioned to the yaw fins 1 and 3,
For this example, the autopilot 14 would provide a control signal to the fin controller 16 to deflect the control fin 1 an amount of 25 degrees, provide a control signal to the fin controller 18 to deflect the control fin 2 an amount of five degrees, provide a control signal to the fin controller 20 to deflect the control fin 3 an amount of 25 degrees and provide a control signal to the fin controller 22 to deflect the control fin 4 an amount of 15 degrees.

It should be apparent, by apportioning all of the roll command, δRc, to the pitch fins 2 and 4 and apportioning none of the roll command to the yaw fins 1 and 3, the angular deflection of the control fin 1 is reduced below the angular deflection limit of 25 degrees.

As a second alternative, if we have an environment wherein the autopilot 14 is fed a pitch command of twenty degrees, a yaw command of fifteen degrees and a roll command of fifteen degrees from the guidance system 12, then the autopilot 14 will provide control signals to the fin controllers 16, 18, 20 and 22 as follows. Calculating the pitch-to-roll command ratio, twenty degrees divided by fifteen degrees, provides the value 1.333. Calculating the yaw-to-roll command ratio, fifteen degrees divided by fifteen degrees, provides the value 1.0. Differencing the yaw-to-roll command ratio with the pitch-to-roll command ratio, here 1.333 - 1.0, provides the value 0.333. Since
the value 0.333 is less than the value 0.5, the pitch-to-roll command ratio is differenced with the yaw-to-roll command ratio, here 1.0 - 1.333, providing the value -0.333. Since the value -0.333 is less than the value 0.5, then the roll command δRc is apportioned between the pitch fins 2 and 4 and the yaw fins 1 and 3 in the following manner.

Since the value of the yaw-to-roll command ratio differenced with the pitch-to-yaw command ratio is less than 0.5 and the value of the pitch-to-roll command ratio differenced with the yaw-to-roll command ratio is less than 0.5, then a first portion of the roll command is apportioned to the pitch fins 2 and 4, the first portion of the roll command being the percentage of the roll command equal to the pitch-to-roll command ratio differenced with the yaw-to-roll command ratio added to 0.5.

For the present example, the first portion of the roll command would equal 1.0 - 1.333 which equals -0.333 which is added to 0.5 providing the value 0.167. Thus, approximately 16.7 percent of the total roll command is apportioned to the pitch fins 2 and 4,

For the present example, the second portion of the roll command would equal 1.0 - 0.167 providing the value 0.833.
Thus, approximately 83.3 percent of the total roll command is apportioned to the yaw fins 1 and 3,

With the foregoing in mind, in the present example of the autopilot 14 being fed a pitch command of twenty degrees, a yaw command of fifteen degrees and a roll command of fifteen degrees, the autopilot 14 provides a control signal to the fin controller 16 to deflect the control fin 1 an amount of 21.25 degrees, a control signal to the fin controller 18 to deflect the control fin 2 an amount of 18.75 degrees, a control signal to the fin controller 20 to deflect the control fin 3 an amount of 8.75 degrees and a control signal to the fin controller 22 to deflect the control fin 4 an amount of 21.25 degrees. It should be appreciated that when the roll command is apportioned between the pitch fins 2 and 4 and the yaw fins 1 and 3, then the pitch control fin with the maximum deflection and the yaw control fin with the maximum deflection are deflected an equal amount. With such an arrangement, the maximum fin deflection required of the control fins 1, 2, 3 and 4 is minimized.

Referring now to FIG. 2, the method as described hereinbefore is shown implemented by the autopilot 14 having a digital computer 50 and adders 62 and 68 and subtractors
64 and 66. The pitch command δPc, the yaw command δYc and the roll command δRc are fed into computer 50. The pitch command δPc is also fed into adder 68 and subtractor 64 and the yaw command δYc is also fed into adder 62 and subtractor 66. Using the technique as described hereinbefore, the computer calculates the value of the portion of the roll command that is apportioned to the pitch fins 2 and 4 (Fig. 1),
which is fed to a multiplier 52 and calculates the value of the portion of the roll command that is apportioned to the yaw fins 1 and 3 (FIG. 1),
which is fed to a multiplier 54. The roll command δRc is also divided by two and fed to a second input of multipliers 52 and 54, respectfully.

The output of the multiplier 52 is fed to a second input of adder 68 and added to the pitch command δPc to provide the control signal
to fin controller 22 to deflect the control fin 4 accordingly. The output of the multiplier 52 is also fed to the subtractor 64 and subtracted from the pitch command δPc to provide the control signal
to fin controller 18 to deflect the control fin 4 accordingly.

The output of the multiplier 54 is fed to a second input of adder 62 and added to the yaw command δYc to provide the control signal
to fin controller 16 to defect the control fin 1 accordingly. The output of the multiplier 54 is also fed to a second input of subtractor 66 and subtracted from the yaw command δYc to provide the control signal
to fin controller 20 to deflect the control fin 3 accordingly.

Having described this invention, it will now be apparent to one of skill in the art that the disposition of the control fins may be changed without affecting this invention. Further, the coordinate system used to describe the invention could be changed from the one discussed.
